titleStmt.title: A survey of evolutionary computation for association rule mining

analytic.title: A survey of evolutionary computation for association rule mining

div.p: This is a PDF file of an article that has undergone enhancements after acceptance, such as the addition of a cover page and metadata, and formatting for readability, but it is not yet the definitive version of record. This version will undergo additional copyediting, typesetting and review before it is published in its final form, but we are providing this version to give early visibility of the article. Please note that, during the production process, errors may be discovered which could affect the content, and all legal disclaimers that apply to the journal pertain.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Data mining is a prevalent and effective technique for extracting useful knowledge from data sources. Association Rule Mining (ARM) is one of the main tasks of data mining. ARM aims to find close relationships between items in large datasets, which was first introduced by Agrawal et al. [3]. ARM techniques have been successfully applied in various fields such as the healthcare industry, market basket analysis, and recommendation systems [18]. Implementation of some frequent pattern mining algorithms is available in the SPMF open-source data mining library [84]. Discovering Association Rules (ARs) in a transaction database is an NP-Hard problem. If there are n items in the dataset, the number of itemsets is 2 n . The maximum number of ARs that can be extracted from each itemset is 2 k -2, where k is the length of itemsets. The time complexity of Apriori-based algorithms is O(2 n )+O (2 k ). As a result, the time complexity of discovering ARs is O(k√ó2 n ) [17]. This demonstrates that the running time is exponentially increased with an increase in the number of items [24]. Traditional ARM algorithms require a considerable amount of computation time. Additionally, they depend on data preparation, before applying the algorithm, leading to a loss of information. Furthermore, a sharp boundary between intervals in numeric attributes and distinguishing the degree of membership for the interval in fuzzy sets are two other drawbacks of conventional ARM methods.

Evolutionary Computation (EC) algorithms are a state-of-the-art and efficient strategy for finding nearoptimal solutions. EC algorithms encode the problem in terms of solution(s) to be evolved to improve its quality. A key characteristic of EC approaches is that strict termination conditions can be set to limit computation time while a nearly optimal solution can be obtained. Additionally, the use of EC algorithms allows association rule discovery without the frequent itemset generation step. This leads to a reduction in time computation [202]. In the last two decades, many researchers have presented the discovery of ARs based on metaheuristics to address the limitations of traditional approaches. Although many papers have been presented in the field of evolutionary ARM, no previous effort has been made to systematically review such methods. Nevertheless, there are a few survey and review papers that cover a small area of evolutionary ARM. A comparative analysis of three evolutionary ARM methods showed the effectiveness of GA for mining Quantitative ARs (QARs) [17]. Djenouri et al. [75] studied the application of three metaheuristic approaches (including GA, PSO, and ACO) to frequent itemset mining and High Utility Itemset Mining (HUIM). Some of the ARM methods that are based on multi-objective evolutionary algorithms can be found in [203]. By 2014, authors categorized algorithms in three types as categorical ARM, fuzzy ARM, and numeric ARM. Ventura and Luna [263] described some of the Grammar Guided Genetic Programming (G3P)-based methods for the mining of ARs. A review of multi-objective optimization in ARM was published [247], which analyzed ARM in terms of different aspects such as chromosome representations, genetic operators, and fitness functions. Badhon et al. [23] presented a more recently updated review as compared to [247]. Del Jesus et al. [57] reviewed evolutionary ARM approaches published by 2011. Ghafari and Tjortjis [91] provided a comparative study of certain evolutionary ARM algorithms. We categorized ARM algorithms into four groups, based on EC techniques, including evolution-based (Genetic Algorithm (GA)-based approaches and Differential Evolution (DE)), swarm intelligence (Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), Ant Colony Optimization (ACO), Honey Bee-based Optimization (HBO), and Bat algorithm), physics-inspired, and hybridization. In each group, we provide a brief description as well as a summary of algorithms and their characteristics. To provide a useful overview, we provide a statistical review of algorithms in terms of different aspects. We also discuss current challenges and opportunities and point out potential trends and applications. In general, the objectives of this survey are as follows: (1) developing a classification framework for the application of EC techniques for ARM;

(2) providing a systematic and comprehensive review; and (3) determining research gaps and proposing suggestions for directions of future research. We expect this survey provides a reference point for researchers and data miners to be informed of the state-of-the-art EC-based ARM methods. Investigating research applications encourages businesses and governments to pay attention to the use of EC-based methods for knowledge discovery in their respective domain.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows: Section 2 provides background information on ARM as well as different types of patterns in ARM. Section 3 presents a classification of EC approaches for ARM. Section 4 discusses current issues and challenges. The measures used to assess the quality of the rules in the ARM process are described in Section 5. Section 6 presents the applications of EC-based ARM approaches. In Section 7, discussion and statistical analysis of the evolutionary ARM algorithms are provided. Finally, Section 8 concludes the paper.

div.head: Association rule mining
div.p: ARM is the process of discovering ARs in transaction data. It is one of the most significant unsupervised methods for pattern recognition [199].

div.head: Definition of ARM
div.p: The basic concepts of ARM are defined as follows:

A transaction database (D) consists of n distinct items and m transactions. I= {i1, i2,‚Ä¶,in} is a set of n items and D= (t1, t2,‚Ä¶, tm) is a finite set of transactions. A transaction t is a set of items in a set I, (t ‚äÜ I).

An association rule X‚ÜíY is extracted based on support and confidence measures. The support of a rule X‚ÜíY, denoted by Œ±, is the percentage of transactions containing both X and Y, where X and Y are the lefthand and the right-hand side itemsets of the rule respectively. The support is calculated as |X‚à™Y|/m, where m is the number of transactions in the database (DB) and |X‚à™Y| is the frequency of the rule. The confidence of a rule, denoted by Œ≤, is the proportion of the transactions that contain X also contain Y.

Confidence is calculated as |X‚à™Y|/|X|, where |X‚à™Y| and |X| are the support counts of the rule and the itemset X, respectively. An itemset is frequent if its support is above a minimum support threshold, donated by Œ±min. A rule is strong when its confidence is above a minimum confidence threshold, donated by Œ≤min [256,257].

The aforementioned type of ARs is known as positive ARs, where only items that are supported by transactions are considered. In contrast, negative ARs consider items that are absent from transactions. For example, these types of rules can be used in market basket analysis to identify items that complement each other. The absence of an itemset X is shown in the form of ¬¨X. For instance, rule X‚Üí ¬¨Y means that the transactions that include itemset X do not support itemset Y [2].

div.head: Types of patterns in ARM
div.p: This section provides basics information about different types of patterns in the ARM process.

div.head: Binary association rule mining
div.p: The ARM process mentioned in Section 2.1 is known as Binary/Boolean ARM, where Frequent Itemsets (FIs) and ARs are discovered in a Boolean dataset. This solely consider whether a thing is available or not in an exchange, without thinking about its quality [135]. Level-wise and pattern-growth are two groups of conventional ARM methods. Eclat [293] and Apriori [5] algorithms mine ARs in a level-wise way. In Apriori, a breadth-first search was used to calculate the support value of itemsets, while a depth-first search using intersection set was applied in Eclat. Apriori is a well-known and widely-used ARM algorithm, which generates ARs with high accuracy. However, its runtime is noticeable long in large datasets [17]. Similar to Eclat, the FP-growth algorithm [104] adopts a "divide and conquer" strategy to mine ARs without candidate creation [256]. Instead of intersection-based-support computation, FPgrowth applies a frequent-pattern tree technique to store all transactions in a tree-based structure [105].

div.head: Numerical/Quantitative association rule mining
div.p: In the real world, most data applications consist of continuous values (e.g., heat, age, income). Mining ARs from quantitative data is known as QARs. An ineffective strategy is to transform the QAR mining problem into a Binary AR (BAR) problem. In this method, for each quantitative/categorical value, the pair <attribute, value> is first mapped to a binary value. Then, BAR mining algorithms are applied. When the domain of an attribute is very large or continuous, this method is not effective [142].

Discretizing the continuous attributes to different intervals is a common way to address this issue. After discretization, the attributes are treated as categorical attributes [24]. For instance, an attribute x with a value between 20 and 100 can be divided into eight intervals (20-30, 30-40,‚Ä¶, 90-100). If a value is 62, the interval (60-70) becomes 1 and the other intervals remain as 0. For example, Age‚àà [20,50] and Salary‚àà [10,20]‚ÜíNumCars‚àà [3,4] is a QAR [182]. The main problem with discretization is loss of information and poor results [59]. Also, the efficiency depends on the defined intervals, while determining appropriate intervals is difficult [199]. In a QAR, attributes can be both quantitative and categorical. Thus, QAR is more expressive and informative than BARs [141].

div.head: Fuzzy association rule mining
div.p: The sharp boundary between intervals is a major problem with discretization-based quantitative ARM. Indeed, existing algorithms for QARs either ignore or over-emphasize values close to the boundary of the intervals. The problem of the boundary is illustrated using an example, as follows. Assume that there are three intervals for income, poor [0, 20K], moderate [20K, 40K], and rich [40K, 60K]. However, it is unreasonable to classify a person with a 19.9K income into the 'Poor' group when an individual with a 20.1K income is classified into the 'Moderate' group. This problem is referred to as sharp boundaries. This challenge can be addressed using fuzziness. The fuzzy set theory [292] is the use of natural languages to represent the concepts. Because of its simplicity and similarity to human reasoning, fuzzy set theory is a popular technique in intelligent systems. Fuzzy set theory transforms quantitative values into linguistic terms, thus generating linguistic or fuzzy knowledge [123].

Fuzzy ARM is the process of using the fuzzy set and Membership Functions (MFs) concepts in mining QARs. Fuzzy ARM makes a smooth transition between a member and a non-member of a set, making the result more interpretative than crisp ARM [42,125]. Unlike the crisp sets in which each element indicates its absence and presence in an interval, fuzzy sets define the degree of a value belonging to an interval. By using fuzzy theory for the attribute of 'Income', we can combine the three intervals with MFs by extending the Boolean values 0 and 1 to the continuous values from 0 to 1 ([0, 1]). The values of 0 and 1 indicate absence and presence, respectively [301]. Fig. 2 shows an example of crisp sets (a) and fuzzy sets of the 'Income' variable (b). According to Fig. In fuzzy ARM, numeric attribute values are represented in terms of linguistic terms. MFs are first used to transform each numeric value into linguistic terms. Then, the scalar cardinality of each linguistic term is calculated on all transactions. Finally, the fuzzy counts-based mining process is performed to find Fuzzy ARs (FARs). In FARs, each numeric attribute ik is related to at least two fuzzy sets. There is one membership function per fuzzy set. The membership function is evaluated to determine the degree of membership of each value of ik in any of its fuzzy sets. FARs is defined as follows [138]:

The rule antecedent is "X is A", while the rule consequent is "Y is B". The fuzzy support value of itemset Z and its fuzzy sets F, denoted as S‚ÄπZ,F‚Ä∫, is computed as shown below:

div.head: High-utility itemset mining
div.p: The process of frequent itemset mining aims to discover an itemset only based on the frequency. This is not an efficient way to find itemsets associated with high profit because itemsets with high utility usually have low support [166], whereas, frequent itemset mining extracts a large amount of FIs with low utility. Two measures, support and utility, are often conflict with each other. In other words, higher support of an itemset leads to lower utility, whereas lower support of an itemset often leads to higher utility [295]. To handle this limitation, HUIM [35] aims to discover itemsets using the factors of quantity and profit. If the utility value of an itemset is greater than the utility threshold, it is considered as a High Utility Itemset (HUI) [295]. Additionally, internal utilities are required, such as the count of items in transactions.

div.head: Class association rule mining
div.p: Classification and ARM are two widely-used techniques in the real world [90]. The integration of these models is a new trend in data mining [209]. Indeed, a classification rule is another example of an association rule. ARs have been successfully applied to classification, and the simulation results showed that it could achieve promising accuracy. Unlike an association rule that includes several items in the consequent part, a classification rule consists of the class attribute only [203]. A common strategy for extracting class ARs is to mine ARs in the first stage, and then ARs with only the class attribute in the rule consequent are determined as class ARs. These patterns are useful in domains that need to predict or classify a certain target. For instance, class ARs are used in medicine for predicting the chances of breast cancer occurrence based on a given dataset [178].

div.head: Rare association rule mining
div.p: Although discovering frequent relationships between items is the primary goal of ARM, mining rare and infrequent associations is another application of ARM. These types of patterns are useful in different domains such as network intrusion [157], banking frauds [231], biomedical data [214], and security. Since strong ARs represent the expected patterns, rare ARs are more critical in such applications. This is because important information is usually hidden behind non-frequent, unusual, and exceptional relationships. Rare ARs (RARs) represent abnormal or unexpected behaviours; therefore, they are supported by only a few transactions. However, RARs help to understand the new phenomena occurring in the domain [213]. For example, in an educational system, an instructor can verify unusual learning problems. A teacher discovers those students who need special support for learning. In medicine, RARs help doctors identify rare diseases or adverse reactions of drugs [147]. Early studies addressed the problem of finding RARs by using frequent pattern mining algorithms, most of which were designed based on Apriori algorithm, which were not effective.

div.head: Evolutionary computation for ARM
div.p: Due to the nature of high-dimensional spaces, ARM is difficult to solve. Therefore, traditional heuristic methods cannot provide sophisticated solutions, which have resulted in increased popularity of non-exact innovative optimization approaches known as EC algorithms. These approaches use an iterative heuristic process to search the problem space through an iterative heuristic process and produce a sufficiently good solution [227]. Single solution-based and population-based are the two main categories of metaheuristic algorithms. In the former, called trajectory methods, an algorithm starts from an initial random solution. Then, it iteratively generates a new solution using the old one until a specified number of iterations are reached. Simulated Annealing (SA) and Tabu search are two examples of single solution-based algorithms. A population-based approach starts from a set of initial random solutions. The algorithm tries to reach a sub-optimum solution through probabilistic nature-inspired operators that bring the population progressively closer to better solutions. Some examples are GA, PSO, and ACO.

There is another classification for EC algorithms: nature-inspired and non-nature-inspired algorithms [53]. Nature-inspired algorithms are categorized into four groups: bio-inspired, physics-inspired, geography-inspired, and social culture-inspired. Bio-inspired algorithms are influenced by biological science. Swarm intelligence-based and evolution-based algorithms are two classes of bio-inspired algorithms; the origin of these approaches is the biological behavior of natural objects. Swarm intelligence approaches simulate the collective behaviors of social swarms of birds or insects that live in a colony. Evolution-based algorithms are inspired by Darwinian principles of nature's capability to evolve living beings that are well-adapted to their environment. Physics-inspired algorithms that search the problem space are derived from physical/chemical rules. Two examples are SA and Gravitational Search Algorithm (GSA). Geography-inspired algorithms generate random solutions in the geographical search space; Tabu Search falls into this category. Social culture-inspired algorithms are inspired by the social and cultural systems for optimization. The Memetic Algorithm is a good example of this type of algorithm, which uses local heuristic search to imitate the mutation process. In addition to nature-inspired metaheuristics, some non-nature-inspired algorithms are inspired by sources that are not related to nature such as human society. For example, league championship algorithm [132] simulates a championship environment with artificial teams that play in an artificial league for several iterations.

In the ARM field, many EC algorithms have been used to address the challenges of traditional ARM algorithms in terms of reducing time and the number of patterns extracted from large-scale datasets. This section follows the classification presented in [53] and presents a detailed survey of the applications of EC algorithms in ARM. A classification of evolutionary ARM algorithms is presented in Fig. 3. Of the 218 ARM methods, the majority used GA to mine ARs (54%; 119 out of 218). Because of the large number of genetic-based methods, they are divided into three groups: basic GA, Genetic Programming (GP), and Multi-objective GA (MOGA). A brief description of the evolutionary algorithms in each group along with a tabular summary of them is provided in the following subsections.

div.head: Evolution-based algorithms
div.p: Evolution-based algorithms are stochastic search methods based on evolutionary ideas from natural selection and genetics. These algorithms use biological operators such as crossover, mutation, and natural selection. Strong adaptability and self-organization are the two main features of these algorithms. In evolution-based algorithms, the entire population is replaced by a new generation using natural operators such as crossover and mutation. The following sections describe recent developments in GA and Differential Evolution (DE) for ARM.

div.head: GA for association rule mining
div.p: GA [115] is the most popular and widely-used EC technique. A basic GA consists of five phases: initialization, evaluation, reproduction, crossover, and mutation. The common representation of a chromosome is a fixed-length binary string. The initial population is randomly generated at the start of the GA algorithm. Each chromosome is evaluated using a fitness function in order to select individuals for producing offspring using a selection mechanism. The operators of crossover and mutation transform the population into a new one with higher fitness values [28]. There are diverse individual representations and fitness functions. To demonstrate the contribution of GA to ARM, we illustrate crossover and mutation operators as well as fitness function for mining QARs using an example described in [22,186,189,190]. Fig. 4 (a) shows the representation of an individual with n genes, where n is the number of attributes. Each gene represents the upper limit (ùëô ùëñ ) and lower limit (ùë¢ ùëñ ) of the intervals of each attribute. The second row of the individual indicates the contribution of the gene to the rule using three values. When the gene belongs to the antecedent or consequent, the corresponding values are 1 and 2, respectively. The value 0 indicates that the attribute does not belong to the rule. Mutation is the process of modifying a value of randomly selected individuals. In our example, mutation of a gene is performed on both the type and the intervals of the attribute. Fig. 6 shows two examples of mutation: a null mutation that changes the type of attribute (Fig. 6a) and a limit mutation in which a random value is subtracted from the upper limit of the second gene (Fig. 6b). Fitness function is used to determine the best candidates. It is reasonable to combine certain measures in a function to obtain individuals with high quality. An example of a fitness function that combines four measures is shown below:

where ùõº, ùõΩ, ùëõùê¥ùë°ùë°, and ùê¥ùë£ùëî are support, confidence, the number of attributes appearing in the rule, and the average size of intervals of the attributes that compose the rule, respectively. The values of ùë§ 1 , ùë§ 2 , ùë§ 3 , and ùë§ 4 are the weights that drive the search.

The use of GA for ARM was formally described for the first time by Wang and Bridges [266]. Some studies applied GA in the post-processing phase of conventional ARM algorithms, where Apriori is used first to mine ARs and then GA is used to optimize the rules [102,232]. Haldulakar et al. [102] designed a fitness function based on the concept of supervised learning for searching the cut-points of continuous attributes. Other research efforts improved the basic GA in the phases of mutation [98] and crossover [246] for ARM purposes. Guo and Zhou [98] applied an adaptive mutation rate in such a way that the mutation probability for all chromosomes is calculated in each iteration; however, this resulted in a high execution time. In [270], the matrices of crossover and mutation were adopted in an adaptive GA-based ARM. ARM with GA (ARMGA) [278] is a well-known algorithm for mining BARs; the main drawback of this algorithm is the generation of not admissible solutions. Improvements to ARMGA have been presented. Kabir et al. [130] extended ARMGA by applying multiple seeds strategy to generate an effective initial population from each seed based on Euclidean distance. As with ARMGA [278], their method follows the Michigan strategy of encoding each rule into a single chromosome. ARMGA was also enhanced in [279] to extract positive QARs using a generalized FP-tree. Both algorithms use only confidence as a fitness function as well as a single seed chromosome for generating an initial population. A similar method with ARMGA was developed for extracting both positive and negative QARs but without generating FIs [8]. In addition to generating a uniform initial population instead of a random one, an adaptive mutation probability is used for discovering ARs. Unlike ARMGA that adopts a two-point crossover, this method used a simple crossover.

Multi-level ARM is an efficient strategy for discovering relationships between attributes. Most ARM algorithms discover ARs at a single concept level. In some applications, it is required that associations are extracted at multiple concept levels. For example, a decision maker does not need information about wheat bread and white bread, which are two kinds of bead. Therefore, the rule "bread‚üπmilk" may be more helpful to the decision maker than the rule "wheat bread‚üπjuice milk". Extracting ARs at different levels is more informative than only one single level. Concept taxonomy is essential for mining multilevel ARs in which primitive-level concepts are generalized to high-level ones. At every level of abstraction, there is its own minimum support threshold. Items in the higher level have higher support and vice versa. Therefore, to find associations in low concept levels, minimum support should be reduced. Different minimum supports/confidences can be considered at different levels [277]. Xu et al. [277] adopted GA for mining multi-level ARs using tree-based genetic operators. In the case of FARs, the MFs of each item are encoded into a chromosome based on a given taxonomy [37,38,52].

Djenouri et al. [65] proposed the delete and decomposition strategy for dividing a rule into two rules if an item appeared in both the rule antecedent and the rule consequent. The item is removed from both parts of the two rules. The authors proposed an algorithm based on incorporation of this strategy and genetic approach for the frequent itemset mining problem [66]. Then then improved the algorithm using a framework that considers the recursive property of FIs in search of the solution space [66,67,68].

The problem of applying fuzzy sets in GA-based ARM for tuning MFs based on the similarity of fuzzy ARs was first published by Wang and Bridges [266]. One of the main challenges with fuzzy ARM is finding a set of suitable MFs. Kaya and Alhajj [135,138] proposed a GA-based clustering method for finding a given number of MFs. The MFs with the optimum centroid points are used to extract ARs. Another clustering-based method was proposed by Chen et al. [40,41] in which a database is clustered through k-means to reduce the runtime and database scanning. However, this method is not efficient because evaluating chromosomes in clusters requires a significant amount of time. Additionally, Chen et al. [39] proposed a solution for extracting linguistic terms and their MFs for quantitative data. Each individual consists of two kinds of genes: control genes for determining whether MFs are active and parametric genes that encode MFs for an item. Hu et al. [124] proposed a GA-based ARM for finding FARs for classification problems. The number and shapes of MFs in each attribute and the minimum fuzzy support are automatically determined by a binary chromosome. The fitness value is the maximization of classification accuracy rate and the minimization of the number of fuzzy rules. In [139], MFs were optimized such that support and confidence were minimized. MFs are selected by maximizing the number of large itemsets and the confidence interval average. In the method proposed in [13], 2-tuples linguistic representation was used to reduce the search space. Palacios et al. [218] applied 3-tuples linguistic representation to derive MFs, and then an FP-growth-based algorithm was adapted using the MFs. A new chromosome representation for MFs considering the structure of MFs and their relationship was presented in [259]. Two heuristics were proposed to reduce inappropriate arrangement of MFs and reduce the search space.

Memetic Algorithms (MAs) are a type of metaheuristics that combine a set of local evolutionary searches with an evolutionary framework [206]. A robust MA consists of a list of local search algorithms that have various working mechanisms in order to allow exploration under complementary perspectives. Thus, balancing global and local search represents the successful functioning of an MA [207]. Ting et al. [258] tried to improve poor local search of GA by designing a local search operator and incorporating it into a GA as an MA for enhancing search capability of GA. They used this MA method for optimizing MFs in fuzzy ARM.

Since certain EC methods such as GAs suffer from long computation times, the evaluation of chromosomes is challenge. Different mechanisms that reduce the time complexity of chromosome evaluation have been presented. Hong et al. [116] used a combination of large 1-itemsets and MFs to evaluate chromosomes. Since computing large 1-itemsets is time-consuming, Chen et al. [47,51] enhanced the approach [118] through k-means to cluster a population into groups, which accelerated the evaluation process. Chen et al. also improved approach [47] by using a two-phase method: minimum support and MFs are found in the first phase, while fuzzy rules are extracted in the second step [43]. Chen et al. also presented a divide-and-conquer strategy [42] for handling the problem of runtime in which there is a population for the minimum support of each item and MFs. The best MFs of all populations are used to mine FARs. Hong et al. proposed a similar divide-and-conquer GA strategy for mining FARs [116,117]. The authors [119,120] also designed a parallelization of [118] using master/slave architecture in which GA is performed on master processors, while the fitness evaluation tasks are distributed on slave processors. Chamazi et al. [33] combined the master/slave parallel architecture proposed in [119] and the clustering-based ARM technique [40,41,47] to reduce the evaluation runtime of chromosomes. CPU/GPU architecture is another strategy for handling the problem of discovering ARs in big data. All rules are generated using a multi-core CPU from several independent sub-spaces, while the rules are evaluated on Graphics Processing Units (GPU) [59,60,61]. The parallelization of approach [65] on GPU architecture was proposed to address extensive datasets in real-time. Chen et al. [48] improved a gene expression programming algorithm using the properties of Niche technology to mine ARs from big data. The entire population is divided into several niches and the evolution operators are applied on each niche separately. Dash et al. [55] adopted parallel GA to speed up evaluation of the fitness function.

In terms of the numeric ARM, GENetic ARs (GENAR) algorithm [193] is the first effort that includes minimum and maximum intervals for each quantitative attribute. The length of each rule is equal to the number of attributes, while rule consequent is shown as the last attribute. Fitness function was designed using the number of covered records. Genetic ARs (GAR) algorithm [194,195], which is an extension of GENAR [193], mines FIs without attribute discretization. In both GAR and GENAR algorithms, each individual is represented by three groups of genes. In each group, the first gene represents the attribute while the remaining genes indicate the minimum and maximum limits of the interval. One limitation is that the size of individuals may be different across populations. This leads to degradation of the performance of the crossover and mutation operators. GAR algorithm was extended in [153] for data with both continuous and nominal variables. The aforementioned methods perform a discretization procedure in the pre-processing phase, which leads to a reduction in the performance of the quantitative ARM process. Some studies attempted to perform ARM without discretizing continuous attributes in a time series database [22,185,186,189,190,269]. Indeed, the intervals are obtained in the evolutionary phase.

Recently, some studies combined GA with machine learning techniques such as artificial neural network [269] and self-organizing map [146] to effectively perform ARM. In the latter work, a self-organizing map was utilized first to generate accurate clustered frequency patterns, and GA was then used to generate positive and negative ARs. A hybrid temporal ARM method was presented in [271] that improved the accuracy of traffic predictions, as follows. First, a clustering algorithm, DBSCAN, is applied to find the traffic environment. Then, temporal ARs are extracted using a GA-based rule mining approach. Finally, a classification mechanism is used to predict traffic congestion level.

Additional applications of GA have been presented, including itemset mining in dynamic datasets [236,237,264], FIs [97], HUIs [131,244], class ARs [215], QARs [148,180,233] based on fitness sharing [95], FARs [14], and temporal ARs [196].

Table 1 provides an overview of all GA-based methods. The main idea of some algorithms is only to apply GA to a certain type of pattern or to speed up the evaluation process of a fitness function using a parallelization paradigm. Overall, these papers show that the application of GA in ARM has yielded reasonable performance. Our review demonstrates mining ARs in quantitative data using fuzzy and quantitative ARM has attracted more attention. The GA approach performs a large number of evaluations, which leads to high computational costs, especially with dense or large datasets that possess a large number of patterns. Although it seems that GA-based algorithms struggle to solve this problem, few studies have focused on reducing the impact of big data on performance. Most papers focused on improving performance using different techniques such as designing novel chromosome representations, improving genetic operators, and clustering.

div.head: Genetic programming for association rule mining
div.p: Genetic programming (GP) is a well-known type of GA for optimizing computer programs. GP represents a problem as a tree, whereas GA uses a string structure [87]. In contrast to GA, the size of individuals is not fixed in GP [28]. GNP is another improvement of GA, where the genome is a network structure that is used to handle the low search efficiency of GP [114]. Because of directed graph structures, GNP can efficiently address complex problems better than GA and GP. To avoid the bloating problem, GNP uses a pre-defined number of nodes to build the graph [286].

Fig. 7 shows the basic structure of GNP with three types of nodes: start node, judgment node, and processing node. A start node indicates the first position to be executed. A judgment node serves as decision functions and determines the next node. The processing node represents certain functional actions. In our example, there is one start node (1), two judgment nodes (2,4), and two processing nodes (3,5). As shown in Fig. 7, once node 1 starts, node 2 is activated. Then, there are two possible nodes to be started; i.e., nodes 3 and 4. The next node may be selected with equal probability. In the GNP-based ARM, items and their values correspond to the functions of the judgment nodes. Association rules are represented using the connections of judgment nodes. There is a processing node for each judgment node. An attribute is moved to another judgment node if it is satisfied. Otherwise, it is moved to another processing node. GNP-based ARM has attracted recent attention [177,238]. These contributions are focused mostly on class ARs. The use of GNP for ARM was first proposed by Shimada et al. [238] for discovering class ARs. Attributes of the database correspond to judgment nodes, and ARs are represented by the connections of nodes. Yang et al. [286] used GNP to rank class ARs by generating the appropriate equations. The authors [288,289] also applied GNP to rank the rules based on the semantic similarity between the rules as well as assigning keywords. GNP was applied to adjust parameters such as support, confidence, and chi-squared value. Three other GNP-based classification ARM methods for detecting network intrusions on a database with both discrete and continuous data have been proposed [49,50,167,177]. Two other GNP-based methods were published that addressed continuous data [251,252]. The advantages of these two methods are discretizing values and identifying FIs are not required. A keyword-based method was proposed in [2] for ranking the rules by calculating their relationship to keywords.

G3P is an extension of GP that uses grammar to apply constraints on GP trees [174]. In G3P, each individual is a derivation tree that is generated using context-free grammar, where grammar constraints are generated by applying a set of productions rules. Maximum tree depth is determined in order to avoid very deep trees. Fig. 8 presents an example of context-free grammar defined to the G3P. Context-free grammar is a four-tuple definition (‚àë , ùëÅ ‚àë , ùëá P, S), where ‚àë ùëÅ and ‚àë ùëá are the alphabet of the terminal and non-terminal symbols (‚àë ùëÅ ‚à© ‚àë = ‚àÖ ùëá ), respectively. A number of the production rules from the set P are applied to start from the start symbol S to encode a solution using a G3P. A production rule is represented by ùõº ‚Üí ùõΩ, where ùõº ‚àà ‚àë ùëÅ and ùõº ‚àà {‚àë ‚à™ ùëÅ ‚àë ùëá } * . An initial version of G3P for ARM was presented for extracting ARs with only a single item in rule consequent [173,174]. In the G3P for ARM (G3PARM) algorithm [173], context-free grammar was used to constrain the individuals. Luna et al. [175] adapted the idea of G3PARM for discovering RARs. The authors applied four fitness functions that avoid noise from RARs. Luna et al. [171] used G3P to automatically adapt parameter values in order to optimize continuous ARs, which helps non-professional users of EC. A G3P-based algorithm for extracting exceptional relationships was presented in a similar way to G3PARM [170]. Luna et al. [176,168] and Romero et al. [229] proposed G3P-based rule mining algorithms in order to detect students' behaviors in education systems. Padillo et al. [217] parallelized G3P for mining RARs in big data in a parallel manner using emerging Spark and Flink technologies. Luna et al. [169] formulated the problem of mining context-aware association rules. Padillo et al. [216] applied G3P in order to handle the ARM in big data through distribution strategy, where parallel paradigms such as MapReduce are used.

Table 2 summarizes typical studies of GP for ARM. In summary, GP for ARM has been applied less frequently as compared to GAs. Most algorithms have focused on class ARs and binary ARs, because of the easier implementation and straightforward representation of GA. Additionally, GP can be used as a search algorithm and also as a classification algorithm. Due to flexible representation, GP-based methods can handle large-scale datasets. One challenge is that this representation makes it difficult to use the design of the genetic operators in GP. Compared with the GNP technique that has not been used in recent years, G3P has recently been applied to the ARM problem, especially from 2011 to 2018. This is due to the superiority of G3P relative to GNP. The encoding strategy of G3P enables the evolutionary process to be started with feasible individuals. In each iteration, individuals with inappropriate fitness values are removed in order to maintain individuals with relevant association rules.

div.head: Multi-objective GA for association rule mining
div.p: Multi-objective optimization attempts to achieve a trade-off between different conflicting performance measures/objectives using a set of non-dominated solutions [202]. For example, ARs can be evaluated in terms of both their support and confidence. According to the user's preferences, a single solution is selected from the set. This schema is mainly used in classification and clustering. On the other hand, in ARM, all non-dominated solutions that represent rules are considered to be the final set.

MOGA has become increasingly popular in the ARM area and several ARM methods have used multiple measures in the evaluation process. Research on MOGA for ARM started in 2004, in which MOGA was used for the discovery of MFs [16,136,137]. In [137], large itemsets and the time required to determine fuzzy sets were defined as two objectives. Pareto-based GA [303] was used to address the conflict of the objectives. Support, confidence and number of fuzzy sets were used in [136] as three objectives. Chen et al. [36] proposed multi-level MOGA for mining MFs and FARs when considering two objective functions: the number of large 1-itemsets of each item and the suitability of MFs in each chromosome. These two objectives were also used in [44,45,46] by adopting SPEA2 in order to find both MFs and FARs. Kaya [133] optimized the mining of FARs by using strongness, interestingness, and comprehensibility as objectives. In [32], Non-Dominated Sorting GA (NSGA)-II algorithm was used to discover FARs by considering the rules describing subgroups as a multi-objective problem. Matthews et al. [197,198] applied NSGA-II to mine fuzzy temporal patterns from quantitative data. Hadian et al. [101] attempted to optimize the support counting phase of ARM by clustering a database according to the transaction size. Qodmanan et al. [224] improved ARMGA [278] using the MOGA approach to extract rules with the best correlation between support and confidence. They applied the FP-tree algorithm to effectively improve the algorithm.

Other studies attempted to optimize ARs using MOGA with multiple quality measures [21,100]. An ARM algorithm based on an adaptive crossover and mutation operators was proposed in [241] for optimizing the rules generated by Apriori. A rank is assigned to each rule based on a fitness function.

Other studies used Pareto-based GA for the problem of multi-objective ARM [94,2] in the field of BARs. Kabir et al. [129] proposed an ARM algorithm for mining BARs through both a class-based mutation and an intermediate generation of a population. The authors also extended ARMGA method [278] using an initialization phase and an adaptive mutation [128].

Regarding HUIM, Zhang et al. [295] considered support and utility as objectives in order to model both tasks of FIs and HUIs as a multi-objective problem. This algorithm does not require specification of thresholds. The authors also proposed an algorithm to mine HUIs using the measures of support and utility information to identify useful patterns [300]. Additionally, an indexing schema was presented for discovering diversified top-k high utility patterns.

Most of the studies of MOGA-based ARM have focused on mining ARs in quantitative data. Minaei et al. [199] attempted to avoid producing ARs with high confidence but meager support using Pareto theory technique. Ballesteros et al. [188] developed a method for discovering gene associations from microarray data without a discretization step. Luna et al. [174] used G3P to propose two approaches based on NSGA-II and SPEA-II. Ballesteros et al. [184] combined a windowing-based learning scheme and MOGA to extract QARs from large-scale datasets. First, a data instance is partitioned into different subsets, and the fitness of the population is then calculated using a round-robin approach. Fung et al. [85] proposed a MOGA-based algorithm for extracting ARs related to user's preferences. Ballesteros et al. [191] adopted NSGA-II to discover QARs. Crowding distance used by NSGA-II was replaced to sort the solutions for each Pareto-front. Almasi and Abadeh [17] decomposed ARM into different sub-problems in order to extract RARs from quantitative data. Each problem is solved using a different initial population. Mart√≠n et al. [181,182] extended NSGA-II for QARs to perform evolutionary learning of the intervals of the attributes and a condition selection for each rule. NSGA-II-QAR algorithm [181] utilizes a multi-point crossover. Two different mutations are used for two parts of a chromosome. In [183], a similar strategy was applied to discover positive and negative QARs based on MOEA/D-DE [159].

Although the focus of MOGA-based algorithms was to increase the optimality of ARM, a few papers considered computational computation [56,298]. In [56], ARM on big data was addressed using two models: data distribution and control parallelism. In the first model, data are partitioned and distributed across the processors. The initial population is replicated to processors. Each processor computes the fitness of each individual using the local data. Then, the master processor accumulates all received fitness values. The second model first clusters the processors using nearest-neighbor techniques. The population is then distributed among the group members. Zhang et al. [298] reduced the time-consumption of rule evaluation using an attribute index strategy, where only one scan of the database is needed.

Recently, Altay and Alatas [19] investigated multi-objective optimization for numerical ARM in comparison with single-objective optimization algorithms. They used eight metrics and 10 real-world datasets in their experiments. Experimental results demonstrated that algorithm proposed by Gosh and Nath [94] is the most effective method in terms of average support and confidence in datasets with high number transactions and attributes. On the other hand, QAR-CIP-NSGA-II [182] could achieve the best results in datasets containing few records and attributes.

Table 3 reviews MOGA-based ARM methods in terms of pattern type and the number of objectives. Based on our investigation, the measures of support, confidence, interestingness, and comprehensibility are the most frequently used criteria for evaluating the quality of ARs. Most of the algorithms applied Michigan encoding and, therefore, all the non-dominated solutions are considered as the final solutions. These algorithms try to optimize ARM either using different useful objectives or Pareto-based approaches such as NSGA-II and SPEA2. More algorithms focused on three-objective optimization than two-and four-objective optimization. Most of the work has been focused on binary ARs, numeric ARs and fuzzy ARs methods, and there are only a few algorithms that address other types of patterns. ÔÄ≠ ÔÄ≠ ÔÄ≠

div.head: Differential evolution for association rule mining
div.p: DE [248] is a simple and strong population-based algorithm and has emerged as one of the most competitive and versatile families of evolutionary computing approach for solving numerous real-world problems [208]. Genetic-based operators such as crossover, mutation, and selection are used in the DE algorithm. Even though the evolution process of DE is similar to GA, it relies on a mutation operation instead of crossover [260]. DE is performed based on the differences between pairs of solutions that guide further search [54]. The operations of mutation, crossover, and selection are performed using Eqs. ( 2), (3), and (4), respectively [20].

In Eq. ( 2), G indicates the current generation and F is the scaling factor used to determine the exploration length (ùë• ùëü2 -ùë• ùëü3 ). There are two types of crossover: binary (uniform) crossover and exponential crossover. Eq. ( 3) presents the binary crossover. In this equation, ùëüùëéùëõùëë ùëñ,ùëó [0,1] is a random number between 0 and 1 and CR is the crossover rate. Eq. ( 4) compares the quality of the solution obtained by the crossover operator with the quality of its corresponding target vector in order to specify the solution that will survive to the next generation [20]. Choosing values F and CR play a significant role in the success of DE and the convergence speed. The automatic parameter adaptation mechanisms are more beneficial for the performance of DE than a fixed selection. Neri and Tirronen [207] proposed a self-adaptive memetic DE using two local search algorithms in the scale factor space to find the appropriate parameters. Triguero et al. [260] used this method in order to the position adjustment of prototypes in nearest neighbour classification.

The use of a Pareto-based multi-objective DE for mining numeric ARs was the first contribution in ARM field [12]. Support, confidence, comprehensibility, and amplitude were considered in order to formulate ARM as a four-objective optimization problem. The first three measures are maximization objectives while the last criterion is the minimization objective. ARs are directly mined without generating FIs and without determining support and confidence thresholds. Fister et al. [83] presented a DE-based ARM method for datasets with both numerical and categorical attributes. Support and confidence are combined into a fitness function as a single objective optimization problem. A modification of DE was proposed in [297] that is able to strictly control the risk of spurious fuzzy rules through two statistical tests on rules. This algorithm has options of statistical tests on rules, which control the family-wise error rate and percentage of spurious rules under the user-specified level. Table 4 summarizes all algorithms described in this section.

div.head: Swarm intelligence-based algorithms
div.p: Swarm intelligence algorithms are inspired by the collective behavior of swarms such as birds, fishes, honey bees, and ant colonies. Population members of a swarm update their positions so that they fit with the respective environment [283]. This ability of swarm intelligence has attracted great interest in the last two decades, and many swarm intelligence-based optimization algorithms have gained huge popularity in ARM.

div.head: Ant colony optimization for association rule mining
div.p: ACO for solving computational problems was inspired by the foraging behavior of actual ants. Ants randomly start to explore the area surrounding the nest [81]. After finding food sources, ants carry some of the food back to the nest after evaluating the quantity and quality of the food. Ants construct solutions by travelling on a graph. During the return trip, they leave chemical pheromones on their path for other ants based on the quantity and quality of food [87]. This process helps ants to discover the shortest direction between the nest and the good food source that was previously explored by the other ants. Ant Colony System (ACS) [79] is the most popular variant of ACO. In ACS, the state transition and pheromone-updating rules were modified to improve the effectiveness of ACO [276]. Positive feedback and distributed computation are the main characteristics of the ACS approach [122].
Next, we describe the details of ACS using a traveling salesman problem. If the k-th ant is currently in the city j, the next city s for the ant to visit is:

where ùëÖ ùëò (ùëó) represents the cities that have not been visited by the k-th ant; ùúè(ùëó, ùëõ) is the accumulated pheromone on the edge between city j and city n; and ùõº , ùõΩ indicate the relative influence of pheromone versus the distance between two cities. Additionally, q is a random number uniformly distributed between 0 and 1, ùëû 0 is a parameter predefined by the user (0‚â§ ùëû 0 ‚â§1), and ùëÉ ùëò (ùëó, ùëñ) is the probability from city j to city i if ùëû > ùëû 0 . ùëÉ ùëò (ùëó, ùëñ) is calculated as follows:

The pheromone density of the best tour is modified once all the ants finish their tours [80]. The iterative best solution and global best solution are two kinds of updating options. The former selects the best rule among all the executed iterations, while the latter selects in the current iteration. The global updating rule is represented by Eqs. ( 6) and ( 7):

In order to avoid selecting similar tours in one iteration, ACS applies the local updating rule. When an edge between nodes j and s is selected by an ant, the pheromone density at the edge is immediately updated, as follows:

ACS has been successfully applied to optimize NP-hard problems. One of the early works of ACS for ARM was introduced by Kuo et al. [151]. In the first phase, K-means clustering and ACS were combined to cluster a database and, in the second step, ARs were discovered through ACS. An extension of this approach for continuous domains was developed in [152]. Hong et al. [121,122] proposed two ACS-based algorithms for optimizing MFs in discrete space for FARs. These methods were extended to a continuous solution space [273,274]. However, the algorithm presented in [274] does not fix edges and nodes in the search process, unlike other methods that use a fixed route map with the discretized nodes and edges. Hong et al. [123] also improved [122] using a hierarchical search process. Rough searches with large scales are first made in the early generations, and the scales for fine searches are then decreased in reduced search spaces. Wu et al. [275,276] applied ACS to mine HUIs in which solution space is mapped into the routing graph. The proposed algorithm attempts to obtain all HUIs from the starting point when there is no candidate edge.

Ant programming is a new variation of ACO that enhances the ability of automatic programming to build computer programs using ACO as a search technique. In ant programming, a tree structure is used to represent an individual [212]. A multi-objective ant programming was used by Olmo et al. [210] to extract ARs. To limit the search space and ensure the generation of valid individuals, context-free grammar was applied. This approach was improved by Olmo et al. [211] by formulating a Pareto-based fitness function using support and confidence. They also presented a single-objective ant programming for ARM using a scalar fitness function. Two ant programming-based algorithms for rare ARs were developed in [213], one which was based on single-objective fitness function and another was based on multi-objective function using support and lift.

An overview of ARM approaches based on ACO is presented in Table 5. Fuzzy ARM and binary ARM account for the highest number of algorithms. Most of the methods used a single objective as the fitness function, and there are only a few papers on multi-objective approaches. In summary, ACO represents a problem as a graph, which is more flexible than the other well-known metaheuristc techniques such as GA and PSO. However, graph representation and encoding the problem as nodes influence performance. Due to better performance of ACS as compared to ACO, all ARM methods use ACS for evolving the problem. Because of graph traversing and management in ACO-based methods, runtime performance is the main disadvantage. It seems that these challenges are potential reasons why ACO has not been overlooked, particularly with large datasets.

div.head: Particle swarm optimization for association rule mining
div.p: Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) [144] is a population-based optimization algorithm for non-linear numeric problems that was inspired by the behavior of social animals, such as bird flocking and fish schooling [143]. Efficiently, simplicity, and fast convergence rate are the main advantages of PSO. Each particle represents problem solutions and has a velocity that represents a flying direction toward other solutions. There are four concepts in PSO:

( In PSO, the position of the ith particle at the tth iteration is used to evaluate the quality of the particle [9]. Eqs. ( 9) and (10) shows how to calculate the velocity and position of the particle at the next iteration:

where ùë§ is the inertia weight between 0.8 and 1.2. In the original PSO, it was set to 1. A smaller ùë§ causes local exploration, while a larger ùë§ achieves global exploration. Fig. 9 shows the movement of a particle in two-dimensions according to Eqs. ( 18) and ( 19).

div.head: Fig. 9. Movement of a particle
div.p: Rough PSO, which is an improvement of PSO, was used for numeric ARM for the first time in 2008 [11] in which rough values defined with upper and lower intervals were used. Different enhancements were developed and applied to PSO in order to improve the performance of ARM. Alatas and Akin [10] improved PSO that is based on chaos numbers to mine numeric ARs by replacing rough patterns with chaos numbers. The midpoint and radius of the values were used instead of lower and upper limits. They then applied a multi-objective version of this algorithm for classification of ARs [11]. In [156], nonlinear PSO was adopted for mining FARs in order to determine MFs. Each membership function is generated based on the best particle found. Search space is by the 2-tuples linguistic representation [112] to help the particles to obtain the best MFs. Other works used an improved version of PSO for ARM [4,126,223]. The first of these works [4] improved PSO using an additional operator in the forms of mutation of GA. This operator is used after the initialization phase of PSO. FIs are first generated using Apriori, and the improved PSO algorithm is then applied to optimize them. Indira and Kanmani [126] computed control parameters in PSO based on the estimation of evolution state and adapted the inertia weight based on the fitness values. In [223], PSO was improved to control the velocity of an individual swarm using a distance-based adaptive acceleration coefficient control method. Recently, Su et al. [249] improved FPgrowth algorithm using PSO, in which the best support is found by PSO is used by FP-growth. These two steps are followed by information entropy as the degree of interest to measure the effectiveness of ARs. Kuo et al. [149] designed a mechanism to search for the optimum fitness value of each particle through PSO to find the minimum support and confidence thresholds in a binary search space. A similar method was presented in [99] using a weighted PSO. Sheikhan and Rad [235] applied PSO to discover FARs in the feature selection phase of intrusion detection systems. They used PSO to determine a size-adjustment parameter and support and confidence thresholds. A combination of PSO and domain ontology was proposed in [204] to mine ARs without support and confidence values. The mining process is performed by PSO, while the generated rules are reduced using domain ontology in a post-mining phase. Pears and Koh [219] used PSO to assign a weight to each item. During itemset generation, the support of an itemset is multiplied by the sum of the weights of items.

Since 2014, PSO for multi-objective ARM has attracted attention. Tyagi and Bharadwaj [261] used Multi-Objective PSO (MOPSO) for ARM in the collaborative filtering for recommender systems. The support and confidence were considered as objectives. The indirect association between users and items can be discovered, even in highly sparse transactions. Beiranvand et al. [24] addressed numerical ARM using Pareto-based MOPSO. Confidence, comprehensibility, and interestingness were defined as the objectives. The concept of rough patterns was used to show the intervals of values. Additionally, MOPSO has been applied to different fields of ARM such as numerical ARM [150,253,254], Binary ARM [88], associative rules in collaborative filtering [262], and online customer reviews [127]. Some studies solved ARM by BPSO. Sarath and Ravi [234] adopted BPSO for extracting top K-ARs without specifying support and confidence thresholds. Lin et al. [162,163,164] applied BPSO in HUIM using the sigmoid updating strategy in the evolution process. The size of the particle is equal to the number of 1-itemsets found in the pre-processing phase. Each bit indicates the presence or absence of the corresponding item in the HUI. To avoid invalid combinations, an OR/NOR-tree structure was developed in [162]. Djenouri et al. [67,68] applied BPSO for frequent itemset mining based on the recursive property.

Other PSO-based ARM methods are presented for temporal ARs [179], class ARs [178,255], HUIs [244], and positive and negative ARs [2]. In terms of big data, Yan et al. [280] parallelized PSO for extracting QARs.

Table 6 summarizes the PSO-based evolutionary ARM methods described in this section. As can be seen in the table, more research has been done on PSO for a single objective than a multi-objective, and more research has been performed on binary and quantitative ARs than other kinds of patterns. Due to a straightforward representation in PSO and its easy implementation, like GA, rapid developments have been made in PSO for ARM.

div.head: Honey bee-based optimization for association rule mining
div.p: Different behaviors of honey bees such as mating, breeding, and foraging have been mimicked by several honey bee-based optimization algorithms. Most bee-inspired algorithms imitate the foraging behavior of the honey bees. In these algorithms, a random explorative search is used to find promising locations. These algorithms then apply exploitative search on the locations to achieve a global optimum solution [291]. BSO, Artificial Bee Colony (ABC), and the Bees Algorithm are three well-known algorithms that use foraging behavior of bees to explore the richest and the most accessible food sources.

The BSO contains three types of bees with different flying patterns: experienced forager, onlooker, and scout bees. Each bee is associated with a position which represents a feasible solution for an optimal problem. At each iteration, the bees with the best and the worst fitness are selected as experienced forager and scout bees, respectively. Onlooker bees evaluate the nectar information provided by the experienced forager bees to adjust its moving trajectory at the next time. Heterogeneity in flying patterns of bees results in a balance between exploitation and exploration. Scout bees to control diversity while experienced forager bees help the exploitation of search space [7]. Motivated by the success and the power of BSO metaheuristic, some ARM algorithms have been proposed. In one of the early works, Djenouri et al. [74] proposed BSO for ARM algorithm (BSO-ARM) using the delete and decomposition strategy. Two extensions of BSO-ARM have been presented by Djenouri et al. [68,73]. In the first enhancement [73], three different heuristics were applied for exploring the search area. The second improvement includes the use of recursive property of FIs [68], where the regions of the bees are determined and explored rather than performing a local search.

More recently, some large-scale ARM methods based on GPUs have been explored. GPUs are typically equipped by great computing power and a big memory bandwidth [299], so they are suitable for parallel computing for large-scale ARM. BSO-ARM algorithm [74] have been parallelized using CPU/GPU architectures [64,70,78]. Djenouri et al. [70] proposed four parallel versions of the BSO-ARM algorithm using a combination of GPU and cluster workers techniques. Two algorithms follow the master/slaves model, in which the first one sends each bee of the colony to one slave, whereas the second approach performs the entire BSO-ARM on each slave. The other two approaches are based on the same principle of the first approaches. The difference is that they use a different approach in the evaluation process, where GPU threaded is used. The third approach evaluates single rule in GPU, while the fourth approach evaluates multiple rules in GPU. Another extension of BSO-ARM was developed by Djenouri et al. [63] in which the search process and solution generation are performed on CPU, while the evaluation process of the solutions is performed on GPU. The problem with this approach is that performance is closely subject to thread divergence that results from the parallel architecture constraint of GPUs. The authors addressed this challenge through database reorganization [62]. They proposed three reordering strategies based on the block, transactions, and transactions with median value.

Djenouri et al. [58] used the concept of meta-rules [25] for summarizing the rules space in the big data context. Moreover, they adopted a pruning strategy to remove useless ARs. In their approach, CPU/GPUbased BSO was applied to discovery the meta-rules to deal with the computational complexity of the evaluation step. Djenouri et al. [69] performed all BSO steps on GPU, instead of only the evaluation step, to improve the search-ability of BSO. They developed a mapping strategy between data and threads in order to minimize threads divergence. Most GPU-based ARM algorithms only benefit from GPU parallelism for solution evaluation. Djenouri et al. [76] parallelized the other steps of the BSO process on GPU.

ABC [140] was inspired by the intelligent foraging behavior of the honey bee swarm to optimize numerical problems. ABC can efficiently solve multimodal and multi-dimensional optimization problems. Apart from the nature of random selection, it uses fewer control parameters. Liu et al. [166] developed a Pareto-based integrated multi-objective ABC algorithm for the ARM problem. They used four measures that included confidence, support, comprehensibility, and interestingness as objectives. Song and Huang [243] applied a bitmap in order to both transform the representation of information and search space pruning, which can boost the HUI discovery process. The size of discovered itemsets is used to generate new nectar sources, which has a higher chance of producing HUIs as compared to randomly generating new nectar sources.

The Bees Algorithm [222] has similar functions for local search and global search processes as the ABC algorithm. However, ABC uses a probabilistic approach during the neighborhood stage, while the Bees Algorithm uses fitness evaluation to drive the search. The Bees Algorithm was applied in [34] to find suitable membership functions for the fuzzy temporal association rules mining.

Table 7 provides a summary of BSO-based evolutionary ARM methods. Except for two algorithms that extract FIs and HUIs, other approaches focused on mining BARs. Most algorithms aim to parallelize the ARM process in big data to address the high computational complexity of the centralized algorithms.

div.head: Bat algorithm for association rule mining
div.p: Bat Algorithm (BA) [282,285] is inspired by the echolocation behavior of micro-bats to solve optimization problems. In order to balance exploration and exploitation during the search process, automatic zooming is applied. In addition, a frequency-tuning mechanism is utilized to increase the diversity of the population [228]. In the BA, each bat searches for the optimal solution by changing its frequency, velocity, and position. These three values are computed using Eqs. (11)(12)(13).

In these equations, ùëì ùëñ is the frequency of the bat i, which is used to adjust the velocity, ùëì ùëöùëñùëõ and ùëì ùëöùëéùë• are the minimum and maximum frequencies of the pulses emitted by all bats, ùõΩ is a random number between 0 and 1, and ùë£ ùëñ ùë° and ùë£ ùëñ ùë°+1 are the velocities of the bat i at iterations t and t+1. Additionally, gbest is the current global best location and ùë• ùëñ ùë° and ùë• ùëñ ùë°+1 are the locations of the bat i at iterations t and t+1 [244].

A modified BA was proposed for ARM for the first time, called Bat-ARM [107,108]. Then, a master/slave strategy was applied to improve Bat-ARM by dividing the population into different subpopulations [109]. However, one drawback is that the exploration of search space is reduced in Bat-ARM because of the lack of communication between bats in the population. Therefore, Heraguemi et al. [110] introduced three strategies to deal with this issue, called ring, master/slave, and hybrid.
Heraguemi et al. [111] investigated the use of multi-objective BA for ARM as a four-objective problem.

The measures of support, confidence, comprehensibility, and interestingness were considered to be maximized. Song et al. [242] proposed a Pareto-based multi-objective binary BA to mine ARs and FIs, without considering minimum thresholds. They also proposed a fuzzy decimal BA to automatically extract MFs from quantitative data [245]. Recently, BA has been applied to the HUIM problem [244].

Table 8 presents an overview of evolutionary algorithms that use the bat algorithm to evolve populations. Similar to other categories, most of these algorithms aim to both discover binary association rules and to regard ARM as a single-objective optimization.

div.head: Other swarm intelligence algorithms for association rule mining
div.p: Firefly Algorithm (FA) is a swarm intelligent algirithm that animates the flashing patterns and behaviors of fireflies and was developed by Yang in 2009 [281]. In FA, a less bright firefly moves toward a brighter one; otherwise, it moves randomly. The objective function is associated with the flashing light characteristics of the firefly population. Zhang et al. [294] converted ARM into discrete optimization using the discrete firefly algorithm. They proposed a multi-dimension using Pareto rules. Pareto is used as an evaluation method for the evolution of the firefly.

Cuckoo search algorithm [284] is based on the behavior of obligate brood parasites of certain cuckoo species in combination with the Levy flight behavior of some birds and fruit flies [86]. A modified binary cuckoo search for ARM was proposed by Mlakar et al. [200], where each individual encodes the corresponding association rule. All attributes are encoded as binary strings with three extra control bits that determine the presence/absence of the attribute in the rule.

Animal Migration Optimization (AMO) [160] is inspired by the migration behavior of animal groups. This algorithm consists of two processes: the first process simulates how animals move from their current position to a new position, whereas the second process simulates how animals leave the group and join the group during migration. Son et al. [240] used this strategy to reduce the number of ARs by deleting rules that were weakly supported by the data. During the optimization process, the algorithm removes those rules having a high fitness value. This is because the rules associated with a small fitness value need to be migrated, which is done by calculating the migration probability of rules.

Penguins Search Optimisation Algorithm (PeSOA) is a new metahesuristic that was proposed in 2013 [92]. PeSOA is based on the behaviors displayed by penguin during hunting. Gheraibia et al. [93] used PeSOA for ARM to facilitate the exploration of the solution space. They incorporated an overlapping distance to generate only non-redundant rules with low amount of overlap between the mined rules.
div.formula: ÔÄ≠ ÔÄ≠ ÔÄ≠ ÔÄ≠ Multi-objective FA [294] ÔÄ≠ ÔÄ≠ ÔÄ≠ ÔÄ≠ ÔÄ≠ ÔÄ≠

div.head: Physics-inspired-based algorithms
div.p: Physics-inspired metaheuristics simulate the physical behaviors of matter or follow the laws of physics. SA [145], Quantum Swarm Evolutionary (QSE) [267], and GSA [226] are three common physicsinspired algorithms that are used to optimize problems. SA is a single-solution metaheuristic based on the hill climbing method. To reduce the probability of getting trapped in a suboptimal solution, SA uses a certain probability to accept a worse solution and to randomize the local search procedure. QSE is a hybridization of quantum evolutionary algorithm [103] and PSO [144]. QSE defines a Q-bit expression called quantum angle and employs an improved PSO to update quantum angles. GSA is based on the law of gravity and mass interactions. In GSA, the searcher agents are a collection of masses that interact with each other based on the Newtonian gravity and the laws of motion. Unlike SA that is single-solution, QSE and GSA are population-solution EC algorithms.

Nasiri et al. [205] presented a multi-objective ARM using SA. They used support, confidence, and interestingness as three objectives. Ykhlef [290] applied QSE for ARM. Can and Alatas [30] performed GSA for the exploration of numeric ARs. In their algorithm, minimum values of confidence and support are eliminated by GSA. Additionally, the range values of the attributes are automatically adjusted during the time of mining of the rules. Therefore, there is not any pre-processing of the data. Table 10 summarizes all algorithms described in this section, in historical order.

div.head: Hybridization for association rule mining
div.p: Because of the large complex nature of ARM, it is necessary to apply a powerful global search technique.

The current basic EC algorithms should be improved for the ARM problem. A powerful search mechanism can explore the entire search space and exploit local regions. The hybridization of different search mechanisms is a solution that combines the advantages of some EC algorithms to balance between exploration and exploitation. Some studies combined single-and population-solution based algorithms to improve the quality of ARM, because single solution-based heuristics are more exploitation oriented whereas population-based EC are more exploration-oriented [28]. This strategy was first introduced by Liu [165] in which GA was improved using SA and quantum computing to increase the performance of GA in the discovery of ARs in continuous datasets. Mutation and crossover of GA are performed using SA and quantum computing, respectively. HBSO-TS algorithm [71,72] is a combination of BSO and Tabu search for ARM. These approaches were selected because of the diversification of BSO and efficient intensification of Tabu search. Global search is performed by BSO and the local exploration of each bee is then computed by Tabu search. The HBSO-TS algorithm was then extended by Djenouri et al. [77] using two strategies to determine the search area process. A combination of Threshold Accepting (TA), which is a point-based search approach, and Binary Firefly Optimization (BFO) using multi-objective optimization was presented in [88].

Different studies investigated the advantages of PSO in combination with other EC algorithms. Easy implementation and the saving of information of particles are two main advantages of PSO. A hybrid algorithm was proposed in [88] for ARM via the multi-objective hybridization of BPSO and TA. Zhou et al. [302] combined PSO and GSA for ARM. Recent papers presented the integration of GA and PSO to achieve a highly influential search strategy [1,88,201,272,302], which stems from the strength of GA in finding a global solution and the strength of PSO in searching for an optimal solution via collaborative group interactions [201]. A combination of MOPSO and MOGA was proposed to mine ARs [1]. Wu et al. [272] incorporated BPSO and GA for mining class ARs for disease detection. First, the best set of significant variables (predictors) is selected using a GA-based method, and BPSO is then applied as a training procedure to create classification rules. Li et al. [158] combined GNP with the Estimation of Distribution Algorithms (EDAs) to solve traffic prediction problems using class ARs.

Table 11 summarizes all algorithms that combine different EC techniques for the ARM problem. The main idea of all algorithms is to optimize the mining of ARs by hybridization. Only one algorithm extracts patterns in the form of class association rules, while others focused on binary rules. BSO+TS [72] BSO+TS [77] GA+SA [165] GA+BPSO [272] PSO+GSA [302] GNP+EDAs
