div.head: Challenges and problems
div.p: Different issues need to be considered when developing and applying an evolutionary ARM algorithm. Some problems such as large datasets, attribute values, and parameter settings are related to both development and application. Other problems such as MFs and solution encoding are associated with the design of an algorithm. One major barrier to using metaheuristic algorithms in ARM is that considerable skill and experience are required in order to determine suitable parameters, such as minimum support and confidence thresholds as well as the number and shapes of MFs in each quantitative attribute. These parameters have a close relationship with the quality of patterns extracted by the ARM process. These challenges are discussed in the following sub-sections.

div.head: Big data
div.p: Due to recent advances, especially communication technologies such as social media, data generation capabilities have increased dramatically as compared to the last century. Nowadays, as everything is stored, a large amount of data is being produced at a tremendous speed. For example, when we search for a product using search engines such as Google, Bing, and Yahoo, we are producing new data. Big data has four characteristics: volume, variety, velocity, and veracity, which are known as the 4V's model. These characteristics refer to a huge amount of data, various types of data, real-time data, and low-quality data, respectively. Although evolutionary ARM algorithms can obtain high quality patterns, they struggle to solve big data ARM, in which both the number of items and the number of transactions are huge. Most conventional evolutionary ARM methods have focused on small-scale problems and are no longer appropriate and are unable to scale to the size of peta-bytes or zeta-bytes. Thus, it is necessary to develop new algorithms with the ability to extract a higher degree of knowledge from these databases. Parallel computing is a common way to improve scalability [220].

div.head: Value type
div.p: Transaction datasets are categorized into two main groups: certain data and uncertain data. The extraction of ARs from certain data is straightforward because the items that occur in a transaction are known with certainty. Therefore, most studies of ARM have focused on finding either Boolean/quantitative ARs from certain data or Boolean ARs from probabilistic data. Some datasets in real-world applications are uncertain, because there are different errors such as human errors, instrument errors, and recording errors that may be produced in the process of collecting, transmitting, storing, and preprocessing data [221]. Data gathered by sensors are commonly uncertain due to the dynamicity of the environment and their limited ability. In some cases, certain data is changed into uncertain data because of the preservation of private information. ARM in an uncertain database is more challenging than in a certain database.

Conventional ARM algorithms such as Apriori and FP-Growth can only extract ARs from binary and categorical databases. However, mining ARs in the database with numeric/quantitative values is a hard problem. Quantitative attributes are continuous within a wide range of values. Therefore, it is necessary to perform an optimal discretization process for all the attributes, which is a complex and error-prone task. This process divides the domain into different intervals. Obtaining ARs by this procedure makes it difficult to calculate support and confidence thresholds. A sharp boundary is the main problem of discretization, which leads to an inaccurate representation of semantics [24].

div.head: Membership functions in fuzzy ARM
div.p: In fuzzy ARM, each numeric attribute is replaced by a different range of values using the fuzzy theory.

MFs have a critical impact on the ARM results, where different MFs infer different knowledge [39]. In some evolutionary ARM algorithms, the fuzzy sets and their corresponding MFs are provided by an expert. However, this is not an appropriate method to determine them by experts for fuzzy ARM, because it requires much time and these sets can be changed in terms of the criteria that the user focuses on [133]. The best solution is to automatically derive a set of MFs to be used for mining FARs. Therefore, both problems of mining FARs and MFs should be performed simultaneously. In this strategy, an EC-based ARM algorithm is divided into two stages: determining MFs and mining FARs. In the first phase, an EC approach is applied to derive suitable MFs. In the second phase, the best MFs derived by the EC algorithm are used to fuzzify the quantitative transactions [118]. Fig. 10 shows two bad types of MFs for a certain attribute: (a) too redundant, and (b) too separate [123].

div.head: Setting minimum thresholds
div.p: Setting appropriate minimum support and confidence values is a subtle task in ARM [106]. A high threshold results in few rules while low threshold causes many (mostly redundant) rules [240]. To address these problems, some methods extract ARs without specifying values of support and confidence [224,279]. In this case, only the most interesting rules are discovered according to the interestingness measure defined by the fitness function, instead of extracting an unknown number of interesting rules [281]. However, this issue leads to different consequences such as generating a huge search space, producing many invalid chromosomes with rules that do not exist in the dataset, and significantly reducing mining efficiency [110,191]. Considering only one fixed support threshold for all items is not suitable in the real world. For instance, cheaper items may be set at higher minimum supports than more expensive items. Some researchers have tried to perform ARM under multiple support thresholds for each item. This strategy helps to discover all meaningful patterns and even rare but important rules [240]. In real applications, there are hierarchical relationships among items. For instance, wheat bread and white bread are two kinds of bread. Thus, bread is a higher level concept than both kinds [155].

div.head: Solution encoding
div.p: Solution representation is strongly dependent on what sort of data mining task needs to be addressed [1].

There are two well-known schemas that encode binary datasets in terms of individuals: Pittsburgh and Michigan, which were proposed by Holland [115]. The former describes the different ARs with a solution, whereas the latter describes exactly one rule with a solution. Pittsburgh approach is more suitable for class ARM, where the goal is to identify a good set of rules [203]. On the other side, the objective of ARM is to mine a set of good rules; therefore, the Michigan strategy is better. The Michigan technique has been most widely used in evolutionary ARM. The choice of the Michigan approach is beneficial when the aim is to find high-quality prediction rules or detect rare events. Due to the fixedlength ARs in the Michigan approach, it is simple, straightforward, and syntactically short in comparison to the Pittsburgh approach.

Binary string is another type of solution representation. Bits are used in binary solution to indicate the presence and absence of attribute values. The length of a binary string can be fixed or variable. The limitation of this representation is that the binary string should be converted to "IF-Then" rules. However, this type of representation reduces processing speed [219]. This type of encoding is suitable for MFs representation. Hong et al. [118,121,123] encoded the MF of each item into a binary code instead of representing all MFs as a long code. For simplicity, there is a set of triangular MFs for each item. Each MF has two parameters: center and span. Each solution is in the form of a bit-string vector that encodes center and span of MFs based on the quantity range of the item. Wu et al. [275,276] encoded solution space of HUIM in the form of a routing graph for performing ant-based algorithms. This graph is constructed only using weighted 1-itemsets, not all itemsets. All items in 1-itemsets are first sorted in ascending order of their utility. The routing graph is then generated based on the ordered list.

div.head: Parameter setting of evolutionary algorithms
div.p: In addition to setting minimum thresholds, the efficiency of an evolutionary ARM algorithm depends on the metaheuristics-dependent parameters. An algorithm's parameters have a significant influence on its performance, especially on the convergence speed. Some parameters are common to all metaheuristics such as population size, the number of iterations, and stopping criteria. For example, using too small of a population size in DE limits the number of available moves and or premature convergence, while a very large population wastes many function calls on nearly random explorative moves. Each metaheuristic algorithm has some special parameters. For instance, crossover probability and mutation probability are two parameters in GA. PSO algorithm is conducted mainly by using three key parameters that are important to the convergence and efficiency. These parameters are the inertia weight (œâ) and acceleration coefficients (c1 and c2). The value w impacts the convergence speed and controls the impact of the velocity history on the new velocity [9]. Therefore, a suitable value can balance global exploration and local exploration. Also, appropriate fine-tuning of parameters c1 and c2 results in faster convergence and alleviates the risk of settling in one of the local minima. The performance of DE algorithm mainly depends on two control parameters: scaling factor and the crossover rate [268].

Setting a suitable value for each parameter is a crucial issue for the performance of an ARM algorithm. Adjusting the automatic parameter tuning according to the search history is a solution. For example, Alatas and Akin [10,11] used chaos mechanism into the velocity updating step of PSO in which the inertia weight is gradually decreased in a chaotic way. The nonlinear adaption of inertia weight based on the average ideal velocity concept is another solution. Also, linearly decreasing inertia weight over time can enhance the performance of PSO [87]. Wang et al. [268] used ARM for extracting the best pairs of scaling factor (F) and the crossover rate (CR). First, all F and CR values are generated during the entire evolution. Then, all frequent itemset of parameters are extracted using an ARM algorithm. Finally, parameters are generated by comparing fitness values obtained by ARM-based parameters and initial random parameters. Overall, parameter tuning and parameter control are two approaches for setting parameter. Parameter tuning refers to manually setting parameters values in advance based on the experience of scientists and contain rules of thumb. The values are kept fixed during the run. On the other hand, parameter control indicates the optimal parameter settings during evolution [20]. AL-Dabbagh et al. [20] investigated parameter settings with diverse versions of adaptive DE algorithms.

div.head: Search metaheuristics
div.p: As ARM is a NP-Hard problem with complex and large search space, a powerful global search method is required to find solutions with high quality. The stability of the algorithms is important in an ARM task.

A powerful search mechanism results in high-quality patterns and efficiency. Most scientists are not sure what algorithms to select for ARM. Some prefer to select a search mechanism based on its implementation availability or popularity in other domains. Although some new approaches are better for the ARM problem, algorithm implementation is not accessible, which limits our choices. A search mechanism should have exploration and exploitation abilities in order to explore the entire search space and exploit local regions. Many basic mechanisms cannot provide these abilities simultaneously. Too much exploitation leads to quick convergence, however, premature convergence and local optimum are two main problems. On the other hand, too much exploration increases the probability of finding the global optimum solution, but it reduces the optimization process with a much lower convergence rate. Thus, new search mechanisms were improved using different ways, such as involving local search (Memetic algorithms) or hybridization of different EC search mechanisms to provide a balance between exploitation and exploration. Additionally, many EC algorithms are unstable on ARM as they are stochastic and generate different solutions based on different starting points. Selection of the best solutions during the process is another issue that should be taken into account in such a way that appropriate solutions are maintained for the next generation.

div.head: Quality measures
div.p: In order to select the best set of frequent patterns, it is essential to assess their quality. Probability-based measures are often used to evaluate the generality and reliability of ARs. In ARM, the support criterion is employed to measure the generality of ARs. The measures of confidence, lift, and leverage are applied to show the reliability of ARs [189]. Support and confidence are the most widely-used measures in the ARM. However, even though many meaningless and redundant rules are mined, the use of these measures leads to challenges in the process of mining ARs. If the support of a rule consequent is very high, any antecedent can appear in the rules. Additionally, negative associations between items cannot be considered by the confidence measure as the support of rule consequent is not considered [182]. Thus, other measures are used to deal with these issues. However, the measures are obtained using support and confidence. Table 12 presents these measures with their formulation. A brief description of ARM measures is provided below.

ÔÄ≠ Conviction [29]: Conviction measures the dependency between X and the absence of Y (¬¨ùëå). Defining conviction thresholds for rules is a difficult task because of its infinity domain. ÔÄ≠ Lift [225]: Mining ARs based on support and confidence cannot capture the interestingness of ARs.

Lift determines whether a particular association rule is interesting or not. Lift computes the ratio between the confidence and the expected confidence of a rule. Because of the infinite domain, determination of the list is exhausting. ÔÄ≠ Certain Factor [239]: Certain factor measures the probability that Y is in a transaction when only those transactions are considered where X is present. The use of this measure prevents the discovery of misleading rules that are not detected by confidence. ÔÄ≠ Netconf [6]: Netconf measures the interest of ARs based on the transactions that support a rule and its antecedent and consequent. As with a certain factor, netconf can detect misleading rules that are not detected by confidence. ÔÄ≠ Comprehensibility [242]: Comprehensibility measures the number of items in a rule. If the number of conditions involved in the following part of a rule is greater than those in antecedent part, the rule is more comprehensible [199]. ÔÄ≠ Interestingness: The discovery of rules with high frequency in a dataset is more attractive to users.

Interestingness is an essential measure in ARM. One of the conventional methods is to divide dataset based on the existence of each attribute in the left-hand side of the rule. A rule consequent can include different numbers of attributes, which are not predefined. Therefore, this method may be infeasible for ARM. A new formulation using the support values of the antecedent and consequent was presented [199]. ÔÄ≠ Accuracy: Accuracy is a well-known measure in classification context, where the validity of the rules is computed. The degree of match between the predicted values and the actual values is considered. In ARM, it is the percentage of transactions that do not consider both the antecedent and the consequent of a rule. Accuracy takes values in [0, 1] and values near 1 are expected for a high quality and high veracity rule [188]. q(ij, ti) is the internal utility of item ij in transaction ti pij is the profit value of item ij.

Ballesteros et al. [189,192] investigated the influence of well-known quality measures on extracting QARs using QARGA algorithm [186]. A larger coverage ratio results in better MFs.

div.head: Applications of evolutionary association rule mining
div.p: Optimization is applied in engineering and industry in order to minimize or maximize goals. This stems from the limitations of resources, time, and money. Therefore, optimization is far more important in practice. EC-based ARM approaches have been effectively applied to a variety of domains. Generally, the major applications can be grouped into eight categories: market basket, recommendation systems, computer networks, healthcare, environment, industry, education, and road traffic. In the following, the applications of evolutionary ARM for solving different real-world problems are provided.

div.head: Market basket
div.p: The initial aim of ARM was to analyze market basket to find relationships between purchased items. This knowledge of purchased items helps managers with planning store layouts and market policies. Although there may be a considerable number of studies on the ARM techniques and optimization methods in this area, applying EC technique has recently incorporated the formulation of the market basket analysis problem. One of the applications of evolutionary ARM on market basket can be found in [113]. In ecommerce sites (e.g., Amazon and eBay), customers look at a set of different products. Analyzing these observations can provide useful information for both costumers and organizations for personalizing interests and for identifying new trends of users. Lim et al. [161] adopted GA to recognize strong associations between key business activities. This helps decision-makers with the management of organizations. Birtolo et al. [26,27] considered GA to mine user preferences and product constraints.

div.head: Recommendation systems
div.p: Analysis of previous behaviors of consumers provides valuable information about user-personalized interests for products or services. A recommender system tries to offer items to potential customers by applying information discovery techniques. This system can be constructed by the knowledge provided by data mining techniques such as ARM. Zhang et al. [295,300] employed MOEA/D to discover high utility patterns for recommendation systems. Collaborative filtering is one of the basic methods used for generating recommendations [296]. It aims to express the user's preferences as ratings for interesting items. Similarity techniques are used to calculate the nearest neighbors of active users in order to recommend a list of top-k items. Two MOPSO-based ARM methods were proposed for collaborative filtering [261,262].

div.head: Computer networks
div.p: Nowadays, preserving the security of computer systems is an essential task in computer networks. Malicious activities can threaten the privacy, integrity, and network resources availability. Therefore, network intrusion detection has become a fundamental component of protection mechanisms. Three GNP-based network intrusion detection systems have been deployed by mining class ARs [49,50,177].

Fuzzy data mining was presented to mine FARs for intrusion detection [266]. How to reduce the dimensionality of large-scale datasets by ARM is an important research topic. Network traffic data often contains a huge amount of irrelevant and redundant features, which leads to a challenge in the construction of intrusion model for distinguishing between normal and abnormal behaviors. Two evolutionary ARM methods were previously proposed for intrusion detection [235,167]. Tayal and Ravi [255] developed a phishing detection system using a PSO-based class ARM for binary classification problem in order to distinguish between Phishy and legitimate email/website.

div.head: Healthcare
div.p: Applying an ARM process in healthcare and medical environments can help doctors and medical workers with patient treatments. An ARM can be integrated into a decision support system to extract associations between diseases. This not only improves the health of medical practitioners but also reduces the medical costs for both organizations and patients. Kuo et al. [151,152] used ACS to extract ARs from a health insurance database in Taiwan. A combination of GA and PSO was applied for cardiovascular disease detection [272]. The goal was to identify abnormal patterns in cholesterol data to be used in the rule-based decision-making system. Furthermore, the application of EC was presented for medical [153], thoracic surgery [178], and mammogram images [241].

div.head: Environment
div.p: Forecasting the behavior of a climatological time series is an application of ARM. These data, which are received from satellite observations, represent ozone variants related to climate change. Ballesteros et al. [185] applied GA to reveal a relationship between temperature, wind, and ozone. Temperature and wind are included in the rule antecedent while rule consequent contains only ozone. They also proposed two methods that use QARs for analyzing ozone content [189] and atmospheric pollution [190].

div.head: Industry
div.p: Effective product design is a challenge in industry, where companies should develop high quality products that satisfy the feelings of customers. This process not only enhances customer satisfaction in terms of emotional aspects but leads to the success of organizations that use this competitive edge. Jiang et al. [127] employed MOPSO to analyze online customer reviews for effective design of new products. A MOGA-based rule mining was developed in [85] to extract the bias or preference of different design patterns in product design. Reducing defects is a critical task during the production phase. In addition to increasing the resultant product quality, it minimizes reworking and cost over-running. Based on this assumption, ARM can play a critical role in decision-making process in industry. Recently, the GA approach was applied in the construction industry [52] and the garment industry [154]. Studying new design methods as well as obtaining and sustaining loyal customers to maintain a competitive edge is necessary for modern manufacturers. Product-service systems are business models that provide cohesive delivery of products and services. Multi-objective discrete firefly algorithm was proposed in [294] for discovering the association rules of schematic design in product-service systems.

div.head: Education
div.p: G3P allows the user to define the structure of the pattern or the form of the association rule according to the user's preferences. This characteristic is beneficial for educational tasks because knowledge of the instructors is important in this domain. Additionally, as knowledge is analyzed by users with no background in data mining, extracting comprehensible knowledge is an essential task [263]. In an education system, an instructor can use infrequent association mining to identify students who need specific support more so than others. In fact, these associations are unusual learning problems in the learning process of students. Two different methods were proposed in the educational domain using the G3P approach, one research study attempted to discover rare ARs [176], while another study focused on extracting patterns that frequently occurred [229]. However, both methods aim to analyze the information gathered from e-learning systems to identify student behaviors. Luna et al. [168] applied G3P to extract knowledge from Moodle learning management system that is saved as a relational database. Luna et al. studied the behavior of students in a specific course and found that the expectations are strongly related to the time spent in the course.

div.head: Road traffic
div.p: Developing a traffic prediction system in cities can help people avoid getting stuck in traffic and urban officials improve infrastructure. Analysis of historical traffic data plays a vital role in this system. An ARM can satisfy this requirement by analyzing real-time traffic data to predict traffic flow [158]. One of the new applications of GA was proposed by Wen et al. [271] for prediction of traffic congestion. A GAbased temporal ARM algorithm is applied to extract temporal ARs in traffic environments found by a DBSCAN algorithm. A classification mechanism then analyzes the rules to predict the level of traffic congestion.

div.head: Discussion of the applications
div.p: Table 13 provides an overview of the application of EC-based ARM algorithms considered in different domains. GA is the mostly used EC technique, where 16 algorithms applied GA for optimizing ARM.

Considering MOGA and GP as different variants of GA, 24 of 35 methods adopted genetic-based approaches in total. ACO has been used only in healthcare environments. BSO-and BA-based approaches have not been used in real-world applications. Research studies have taken advantage of EC approaches to discover patterns in many different fields. According to our investigation, most of these publications are in the fields of security in computer networks (20%), healthcare (17%), and industry (14%). Fig. 11 presents the distribution of the algorithms in different fields.

div.head: Statistical review and discussion
div.p: Table 14 presents the distribution of ARM methods based on evolutionary techniques and their publication year (between 2000 and 2019). GA is the most commonly used EC approach and has been a popular algorithm since 2000, when evolutionary ARM appeared. Swarm intelligence-based algorithms are the second most widely-used approach after GA-based algorithms. This is because swarm intelligence-based methods can be used to converge to both a single optimum and multiple optimal solutions. Applying HBO-and BA-based approaches in ARM represents a recent trend, which appeared in 2012 and 2014, respectively. One of the advantages of bee swarm over other population-based methods is that there are different types of bees, such as scouts, onlookers, and foragers. Therefore, different types of patterns can be provided by a bee swarm. Overall, most studies focused on population-based algorithms such as GA, GNP, BSO, PSO, ACO, and MOGA. On the other hand, a few ARM algorithms were designed based on single solution-based approaches such as SA method and Tabu search. These approaches start with a single initial solution and move away from it, describing a trajectory in the search space. Therefore, these approaches achieve better exploitation than population-based approaches that have better exploration. One of the most interesting trends in the last few years is hybrid optimization approaches. They often combine population-based and single solution-based approaches to provide a balance between exploitation and exploration. Other SI Parallelization of evolutionary ARM algorithms is one of the major solutions for dealing with big data. Master/slave, MapReduce and CPU/GPU are three main architectures that have been used to deal with ARM in big data. Master/slave architecture is simple and easy to implement, therefore, is one of the most popular techniques. In this model, the problem is evolved on the master processor, whereas the slave processor performs the fitness evaluation of individuals received from the master. This architecture does not often require communicating among slaves. MapReduce is another model for the management of big data in which data is divided into several partitions or groups. A map function is first performed by the worker nodes to generate the results from each sub-problem. Reduce function then aggregates the results to obtain a final output [82]. Only one research publication has focused on this strategy [216]. CPU/GPU architecture is a primary model for dealing with the discovery of ARs in big data. This model consists of two hosts: the CPU host and the GPU host. In this method, ARs are extracted on CPU while they are evaluated on GPU in a parallel manner. The results of the fitness function are sent back to the workers to be used for the next population. Cano et al. [31] presented a methodology for evaluating ARs on GPU so that any ARM algorithm can be applied to the evaluation. A GPU-based model that uses bio-inspired approaches to solve the ARM problem was proposed in [59]. Three well-known evolutionary approaches, including GA, PSO, and BSO, were performed on GPU to discover ARs from big data.

div.head: GP-based
div.p: According to our investigation, 29 methods parallelized the evolutionary process to mine association rules from huge datasets. Fig. 12 presents a distribution of parallelization mechanisms. Based on Fig. 12, the CPU/GPU and Master/Slave strategies have mostly been used (62% (18 out of 29) and 24% (7 out of 29) , respectively). On the other hand, only two algorithms have a parallelized ARM process for each multiprocessor and multi-tread strategies. Table 15 shows the main advantages and disadvantages of EC-based ARM algorithms in terms of four categories: objective, encoding, search mechanisms, and parallelization. ÔÄ≠ Objective: When addressing multi-objective problems, parameters or variables are frequently imprecise due to uncontrollable factors, leading to more complicated problem formulation. Solving multi-objective optimization problems is more difficult as compared to single objective optimization because a mathematically explainable solution does not exist due to the highly complex nature of simultaneously satisfying several objectives. Therefore, determinning a set of points that represent the optimal solutions is important. ÔÄ≠ Encoding: Regarding individual encoding, the Michigan approach uses fixed-length ARs, resulting in simple and straightforward algorithms as compared with the Pittsburgh approach. The choice between Michigan and Pittsburgh approaches mostly depends on the type of rule that needs to be extracted. In class ARs where the interaction among the rules is important, the Pittsburgh approach is more suitable. Binary encoding representation reduces the processing speed. However, it suffers from some limitations: (1) the binary string should be converted to "IF-Then" rules, (2) binary encoding is not appropriate for categorical and numerical datasets, and Single-objective Multi-objective programming and improves program scalability. However, a GPU core is slower than a CPU core so simple computing functions are assigned. Designing more GPU cores than CPU cores is a solution for this problem. Additionally, high-power consumption is another challenge that GPU cannot deal with properly. Master/slave parallel ARM implementations have been popular in the data mining community, mainly due to the fact that this model is conceptually simple and easy to implement. However, applying this model is inefficient when the evaluation cost is not high [96].

div.head: Conclusion and future work
div.p: Association rule mining is currently one of the most active data mining topics. The application of EC techniques for ARM has received a considerable amount of research attention. This paper has provided a comprehensive survey of EC approaches for solving the ARM problem. We presented a classification of evolutionary ARM algorithms along with a brief description of them and a statistical review of methods in terms of different factors. Applications and critical challenges were also discussed.

According to our survey, GA and its variants, including GNP and MOGA are the most popular approaches for discovering association rules. This is due to the smooth implementation and fine performance of the GA algorithm. However, the efficiency of GA is lower than other EC techniques. GNP-based methods have mostly been applied to class ARM in intrusion detection systems. Dealing with quantitative values is the main focus of several methods, in which the methods attempt to either discrete the values into appropriate intervals or use the best MFs derived by EC to fuzzify the quantitative transactions. The application of EC algorithms to the quantitative ARM has attracted considerable interest in recent years. Hybridization is a new trend that attempts to take advantage of the strengths of different algorithms and techniques in order to improve the performance of metaheuristics or the quality of extracted patterns. Hybridization is not restricted to the combination of different metaheuristics but includes the combination of metaheuristics and other techniques, such as fuzzy logic, semantic similarity, and machine learning algorithms including artificial neural network and self-organizing map. Highperformance computing architectures such as CPU/GPU and master/slave enable ARM models for big data. They aim to deal with high time complexity and large search spaces in evolutionary ARM. Therefore, in the past few years, many ARM methods have been developed for big data mining.

There are several concerns regarding real-world applications such as business, industry, security in computer networks, and recommendation systems. These concerns are related to mining useful and informative patterns in terms of frequency or infrequency. To optimize the objectives in these areas, evolutionary ARM methods have been employed in different ways. Compared to other domains, application of evolutionary ARM in industry and business has caught the attention of researchers. In some domains such as education, rare ARs are extracted for identifying students who need specific support. Class ARs based on GNP are widely-used for intrusion detection in computer networks.

Despite the widespread success of EC approaches in ARM, there are several promising directions for additional research of evolutionary ARM. (1) Optimal use of the benefits of the ant bee colony and cuckoo optimization algorithm for ARM purposes. Although EC approaches for ARM have attained some success, they still face challenges and their potential has not been fully investigated. (2) Hybrid metaheuristic algorithms of single solution-based and population-based algorithms can be further considered for ARM. In other words, exploitation of single solution-based metaheuristics can be combined with the exploration of population-based metaheuristics. (3) Because of the increasing number of transactions in many real-world tasks such as the Webdocs benchmark dataset, scalability is one of the most critical issues. Therefore, novel search mechanisms and representation schemes are needed for both single objective and multi-objective ARM. Recent advances in EC for large-scale global optimization indicate that further studies on this area are needed. Although ARM for large volumes of data has made significant progress, no progress has been made for ARM models of high velocity of data. BSO-and GAbased ARM have attracted more attention as compared to other EC approaches. Other algorithms have not considered the big data problem. Therefore, this area is a research gap for the data mining community. (4) There is a lack of studies evaluating the effectiveness of evolutionary ARM algorithms under different aspects, which represents an excellent opportunity for researchers. The effects of each algorithm's parameters such as population size and support/confidence thresholds on the convergence rate as well as getting trapped into local optima can be investigated. Advantages and disadvantages of EC algorithms can be tested on a large number of benchmark datasets/problems. These types of contributions help data miners with deciding which algorithm to choose for knowledge mining.

figure.head: Fig. 13 .Fig. 14 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 13. Distribution of evolutionary ARM methods based on pattern typeLike most real-world problems, ARM is inherently characterized by multiple conflicting objective realizations. Evolutionary ARM algorithms are widely used for generating ARs by maximizing the support or confidence of the rules. However, there are other metrics that evaluate the quality of an association rule in which the aim is to discover ARs while optimizing several goodness criteria simultaneously. Fig.14shows the number of ARM algorithms in terms of the EC techniques and objective problem. Based on our investigation, 56 and 163 of 219 algorithms consider ARM as singleobjective and multi-objective problems, respectively. Based on division of genetic-based algorithms into three groups (GA, MOGA, and GP), all multi-objective-based algorithms were classified in the MOGA group. Overall, 34 of 120 GA-based algorithms formulated the ARM process as a multi-objective problem, which accounts for 28%. All BSO-based methods use single-objective as the fitness function, while other EC-based algorithms address the multi-objective problem. However, multi-objective ARM has attracted less attention than single-objective.

(3) algorithms based on binary encoding often suffer from the dimensionality of the problem due to many possible attribute values. ÔÄ≠ Search mechanism: Each metaheuristic algorithm has their own impacts on the performance of ARM process when is applied for discovering frequent patterns. For instance, PSO-based algorithms are easy to implement; however, they have a slow convergence rate, a parameter selection problem, and are easily trapped in a local optimum due to its poor exploration. Honeybee-inspired algorithms have a slow convergence speed due to two searching phases with equally large populations, which are time consuming. Overall, although swarm intelligence-based ARM algorithms minimize communication overhead through local information and interaction, they can get trapped in stagnation or premature convergence to a local optimum, which makes them unsuitable for time-critical applications. Evolutionary computing heuristics such as GA and DE are usually global optimizers. ÔÄ≠ Parallelization: There are three widely-used strategies to handle ARM on big data: MapReduce, CPU/GPU, and Master/Slave. Although MapReduce is scalable and fault-tolerant with many low-end computing nodes, the number of read-write operations increases when dealing with iterative computation. This leads to high load and time cost. The use of GPU for ARM simplifies

note.p: Recent papers reviewed only a small fraction of evolutionary ARM algorithms, but there have been many papers published in recent years. Therefore, we aimed to provide a comprehensive survey of emerging research of EC techniques for the ARM process. From a variety of papers collected for this study, 214 papers were selected and used for our survey. A total of 219 scientific ARM algorithms were proposed by these 214 papers. Fig.1depicts the distribution of the collected papers published between 2000 and 2019. As presented, the highest number of papers were proposed in 2017 (23 out of 214, 10%). This figure demonstrates that the evolutionary ARM has emerged as a popular topic in recent years.

div.head: Author contributions
div.p: Use this form to specify the contribution of each author of your manuscript. A distinction is made between five types of contributions: Conceived and designed the analysis; Collected the data; Contributed data or analysis tools; Performed the analysis; Wrote the paper. For each author of your manuscript, please indicate the types of contributions the author has made. An author may have made more than one type of contribution. Optionally, for each contribution type, you may specify the contribution of an author in more detail by providing a one-sentence statement in which the contribution is summarized. In the case of an author who contributed to performing the analysis, the author's contribution for instance could be specified in more detail as 'Performed the computer simulations', 'Performed the statistical analysis', or 'Performed the text mining analysis'. If an author has made a contribution that is not covered by the five pre-defined contribution types, then please choose 'Other contribution' and provide a one-sentence statement summarizing the author's contribution.
